label: Project start
keyQuestions: What is the gap in the literature and the resulting research question? || Is funding available to conduct the project? || What are the time plan and work packages of the project? || Who is responsible for what in the project?

label: Unpaywall
descr: If you would like to read an article that is not open access, and your institution does not subscribe to the journal, consider Unpaywall.

label: How to get a paper
descr: How to download academic papers and books for free.
path: Project Start > Literature > How to get a paper

label: Literature Excel organization
descr: No literature review will ever be the same again, if you use this tutorial to organize all your literature in Excel.
path: Project Start > Literature > Literature Excel organization

label: Elicit
descr: Elicit is your AI research assistant that "uses language models to help you automate research workflows", by finding "relevant papers without perfect keyword match", summarizing "takeaways from the paper specific to your question", and extracting relevant information.

label: Connected Papers
descr: To explore connections between published papers (e.g., for a literature review), use Connected Papers. This is also nice to see the reach of your own research! It is a "unique, visual tool to help researchers and applied scientists find and explore papers relevant to their field of work".

label: Snowball
descr: A tool that would find related articles with snowballing method.

label: Research Rabbit
descr: Use Research Rabbit to find both germinal and future works from a single (or multiple) works.

label: Scholarcy
descr: Want an AI to summarize literature for you? Wait no more, Scholarcy comes to the rescue.

label: LitMaps
descr: An all-rounder tool for visual research navigation, citation network search, and team synchronization.

label: 10 ways to OpenAccess
descr: A list of 10 different ways to get to open-access articles.
path: Project Start > Literature > 10 ways to OpenAccess

label: Consensus
descr: A search engine that uses AI to extract and summarize findings from scientific work.

label: Seaboat
descr: This app helps you organize your evaluation of a empirical research, focusing on threats to validity. Read the corresponding paper here: https://psyarxiv.com/fc8v3.

label: Semantic Scholar
descr: A free, AI-powered research tool to find scientific literature.

id: Improving Statistical Questions by Daniel Lakens
label: Improving Statistical Questions by Daniel Lakens
descr: The course aims to help you to ask better statistical questions when performing empirical research.
path: Project Start > Literature > Improving Statistical Questions by Daniel Lakens

label: Brain Interpreter
descr: An artificial neural network that predicts brain activation maps from snippets of text.

label: Open Access Button
descr: Free, legal research articles delivered instantly or automatically requested from authors.
path: Project Start > Literature > Open Access Button

label: MeSH
descr: MeSH (Medical Subject Headings) is the NLM controlled vocabulary thesaurus used for indexing PubMed citations. Use the MeSH database to find MeSH terms, including Subheadings, Publication Types, Supplementary Concepts and Pharmacological Actions, and then build a PubMed search. The MeSH database can be searched by MeSH term, MeSH Entry Term, Subheading, Publication Type, Supplementary Concept, or MeSH Scope Note.

label: Open Knowledge Foundation
descr: The Open Knowledge Foundation creates digital tools, equip people with skills, and expand digitally savvy networks that understand the transformative power of openness.
path: Project Start > Communities > Open Knowledge Foundation

label: Center for Open Science
descr: Their mission is to increase openness, integrity, and reproducibility of research.
path: Project Start > Communities > Center for Open Science

label: Database of Open Science communities
descr: A list of communities promoting/impacted by open science practices.
path: Project Start > Communities > Database of Open Science communities

id: International Network of Open Science & Scholarship Communities
label: International Network of Open Science & Scholarship Communities
descr: INOSC is an international network of local Open Science & Open Scholarship communities (OSC). OSCs are hubs where academics learn from their peers how to make their workflows more open. More and more academics are joining OSCs, ready to put Open Science to practice.
path: Project Start > Communities > International Network of Open Science & Scholarship Communities

label: Global Reproducibility Networks
descr: A Reproducibility Network (RN) is a national, peer-led consortium of researchers that aims to promote and ensure rigorous research practices by establishing appropriate training activities, designing and evaluating research improvement efforts, disseminating best practice and working with stakeholders to coordinate efforts across the sector.
path: Project Start > Communities > Global Reproducibility Networks

label: ReproducibiliTea
descr: A grassroots journal club initiative that helps researchers create local Open Science journal clubs at their universities to discuss diverse issues, papers and ideas about improving science, reproducibility and the Open Science movement.

id: The Society for the Improvement of Psychological Science
label: The Society for the Improvement of Psychological Science
descr: Brings together scholars working to improve methods and practices in psychological science.
path: Project Start > Communities > The Society for the Improvement of Psychological Science

label: Global Young Academy
descr: The vision of the Global Young Academy (GYA) is science for all; science for the future, and its mission to give a voice to young scientists around the world.
path: Project Start > Communities > Global Young Academy

label: RepliCATS
descr: An interdisciplinary group of researchers interested in how structured group deliberation processes can improve scientific processes and practices, from post-publication peer review to improving the generalizability of research to global South contexts.

label: Psychological Science Accelerator
descr: A globally distributed network of researchers that pool intellectual and material resources to accelerate the accumulation of rigorous knowledge in psychological science.
path: Project Start > Communities > Psychological Science Accelerator

label: The Turing Way
descr: An open science, open collaboration, and community-driven project. We involve and support a diverse community of contributors to make data science accessible, comprehensible and effective for everyone.
path: Project Start > Communities > The Turing Way

label: FORRT
descr: FORRT is a Framework for Open and Reproducible Research Training advancing research transparency, reproducibility, rigor, and ethics through pedagogical reform and meta-scientific research.

label: ABRIR
descr: An international consortium of researchers that aims to identify the unique barriers faced by researchers from LMICs (low-to-middle income countries) while participating and leading in Big-Team/Open Science projects.

label: Public Open Science Institute (ZPID)
descr: The supra-regional research support facility for psychology in German-speaking countries. It supports the entire scientific work process, from literature research and study planning to data collection and analyses to documentation, archiving and publication of results.
path: Project Start > Communities > Public Open Science Institute (ZPID)

label: Postdoc funding
descr: Find a list of postdoctoral funding opportunities (there are also separate lists for neuroscience/neurology and cancer/oncology).

label: Brainverse
descr: A neat, open-source, cross-platform tool for notetaking, experiment planning and a labbook tool.

label: Notion
descr: Notion is the best application there is to keep all your (PhD) note-taking mess in one place.

label: Trello
descr: Trello helps you stay organized and work together with others by letting you create lists about anything you want.

label: The Good Research Code Handbook
descr: Organize your code so that it is easy to understand and works reliably.
path: Project Start > Organization > The Good Research Code Handbook

label: Ganttrify
descr: Check out this handy tool to create Gantt charts in R.

label: Miro
descr: You can use Miro for creating visual presentations of anything, and most of all, for collaboration with others! The possibilities are endless.

label: Toggl
descr: Time tracking software to boost performance and get paid for every billable minute. An intuitive tool that makes time tracking painless for the entire team.

label: GitLab Roadmap
descr: GitLab roadmap is a project 'roadmap' tool where you can plan your project in monthly, weekly, quarterly bins with subprojects and assignments etc.

label: Big Team Setup
descr: This guide is aimed at people wanting to start a big team science group from the grassroots, with little or no financial or administrative support.
path: Project Start > Organization > Big Team Setup

label: Time Graphic
descr: Free online timeline maker

label: Study design
keyQuestions: What are the hypotheses and how can they be tested? || Which independent variables (IVs) are manipulated? || Which dependent variables (DVs) need to be measured? || Is approval by an ethics/institutional review board (IRB) needed? || How large should the sample be?

label: Sample size justification Shiny app
descr: If you need help justifying your sample size, use this Shiny app from Daniel Lakens.
path: Study design > Sample size > Sample size justification Shiny app

label: WebPower online tool
descr: WebPower is a collection of tools for conducting statistical power analysis online.
path: Study design > Sample size > WebPower online tool

label: Gpower
descr: G*Power is a tool to compute statistical power analyses for many different t tests, F tests, ?2 tests, z tests and some exact tests. G*Power can also be used to compute effect sizes and to display graphically the results of power analyses.

label: Presentation
descr: Presentation is a stimulus delivery and experiment control program for neuroscience

label: Pavlovia
descr: Pavlovia is a place for the wide community of researchers in the behavioural sciences to run, share, and explore experiments online.

label: Psychtoolbox
descr: Psychtoolbox is an open-source software package used in MATLAB and GNU Octave for creating experiments in the fields of psychology, neuroscience, and vision research. It provides a collection of functions that allow researchers to control the presentation of stimuli and the collection of responses, making it a valuable tool for conducting behavioral experiments and studies involving human perception and cognition.
path: Study design > Design framework > Matlab > Psychtoolbox

label: PsychoPy
descr: PsychoPy is an open-source software package used for creating and conducting experiments in psychology and neuroscience, providing tools to generate various types of stimuli and collect data, often used in research and educational settings.
path: Study design > Design framework > Python > PsychoPy

label: JsPsych
descr: jsPsych is a JavaScript framework designed to develop behavioral experiments that can be executed within a web browser.
path: Study design > Design framework > Javascript > JsPsych

label: Gorilla
descr: The Gorilla Experiment Builder is a cloud based research platform that allows researchers and students to quickly and easily create and host behavioural (reaction-time) experiments online.

label: PsychOpen CAMA
descr: PsychOpen CAMA enables accessing meta-analytic datasets, reproducing meta-analyses and dynamically updating evidence from new primary studies collaboratively.
path: Study design > Data availability > Datasets > PsychOpen CAMA

label: 24 days of databases
descr: Somebody on Twitter was gracious enough to summarize some cool datasets that you can work on.
path: Study design > Data availability > Datasets > 24 days of databases

label: BIONIC project
descr: BIObanks Netherlands Internet Collaboration (BIONIC) Project: This article describes the BIONIC Project, a large-scale Dutch dataset (>100.000) individuals with genome-wide genotype data and informaton on depression-related phenotypes
path: Study design > Data availability > Datasets > BIONIC project

label: Popane
descr: A large database on the psychophysiology of positive and negative emotions. This database involves recording of 1157 healthy participants, collected across seven studies, a continuous recordof self-reported affect along with several biosignals (electrocardiogram, impedance cardiogram, electrodermal activity, hemodynamic measures, e.g., blood pressure), respiration trace, and skin temperature. [The authors] experimentally elicited a wide range of positive and negative emotions, including amusement, anger, disgust, excitement, fear, gratitude, sadness, tenderness, and threat.
path: Study design > Data availability > Datasets > Emotions > Popane

label: NeuroSynth
descr: Neurosynth is a platform for large-scale, automated synthesis of functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data.
path: Study design > Data availability > Datasets > Imaging data > NeuroSynth

label: Study implementation
keyQuestions: What measures are most fitting (tasks, questionnaires, etc.)? || What stimuli need to be created (e.g., pictures, videos, text)? || Which programming environment should be used?

label: Registered Report Framework
descr: Registered Reports is a publishing format that emphasizes the importance of the research question and the quality of methodology by conducting peer review prior to data collection. High quality protocols are then provisionally accepted for publication if the authors follow through with the registered methodology.

label: PRISMA Guidelines
descr: The PRISMA guidelines are designed to help authors transparently report why their systematic review or meta-analysis was done, what methods they used, and what they found.

label: Open Test Archive
descr: A repository for test instruments from various fields of psychology and related disciplines. Currently hosting 238 open access tests, it ranks among the largest repositories in the German-speaking regions and is updated and expanded on an ongoing basis.
path: Study Implementation > Tests > Open Test Archive

label: APA PsycTests
descr: A one-of-a-kind database of psychological tests and measures designed for use with social and behavioral science research.

label: PROSPERO
descr: PROSPERO accepts registrations for systematic reviews, rapid reviews and umbrella reviews. PROSPERO does not accept scoping reviews or literature scans. Sibling PROSPERO sites registers systematic reviews of human studies and systematic reviews of animal studies.

label: OSF Templates
descr: A list of available preregistration templates.
path: Study Implementation > Preregistration Framework > OSF Templates

label: AsPredicted Templates
descr: A platform to upload AsPredicted preregistrations.

label: ZPID PreReg
descr: A domain-specific repository for preregistrations.
path: Study Implementation > Preregistration Framework > ZPID PreReg

label: EMBODY/EMFACE
descr: This is a 2022 published tool to measure how good people can recognize emotions in the body or face.

label: Empathy for pain
descr: Pictures showing hands in painful situations that can be used to assess empathy for others' pain.
path: Study Implementation > Stimulus Material > Empathy for pain

label: Full body stimuli
descr: Need some full-body stimuli in your experiments? Look no further.
path: Study Implementation > Stimulus Material > Full body stimuli

label: KAPODI
descr: A huge database of every emotional stimuli you can think of and may want to use in your experiments.

label: Piloting
keyQuestions: Is the study feasible? || Do all manipulations work as intended?

label: Data simulation
descr: Data simulation in an experiment involves creating artificial or synthetic data that mimics the characteristics of real-world data. This process is commonly used for testing and validation purposes.

label: Feasibility studies
descr: This website is designed to support those conducting pilot and feasibility studies using randomised and non-randomised designs and those carrying out methodological research on these types of studies.

label: Webinars for pilot studies
descr: A webinar series highlighting key points to consider when conducting pilot and feasibility studies prior to a definitive randomised controlled trial.

label: Data collection
keyQuestions: How can we make sure my data is safely stored, accessible, and backed up? || Is the data collected in a way that protects private and sensitive information (e.g., of participants)?

label: formr
descr: Chain simple surveys into long runs, use the power of R to generate pretty feedback and complex designs.

label: BIDS
descr: A simple and easy to adopt way of organizing neuroimaging and behavioral data.

label: 24 days of databases
descr: Somebody on Twitter was gracious enough to summarize some cool datasets that you can work on.
path: Study design > Data availability > Datasets > 24 days of databases

label: Popane dataset
descr: A large database on the psychophysiology of positive and negative emotions. This database involves recording of 1157 healthy participants, collected across seven studies, a continuous recordof self-reported affect along with several biosignals (electrocardiogram, impedance cardiogram, electrodermal activity, hemodynamic measures, e.g., blood pressure), respiration trace, and skin temperature. [The authors] experimentally elicited a wide range of positive and negative emotions, including amusement, anger, disgust, excitement, fear, gratitude, sadness, tenderness, and threat.
path: Data collection > Existing data > Popane dataset

label: Landscaping Longitudinal Research
descr: Landscaped longitudinal datasets from across the world
path: Data collection > Existing data > Landscaping Longitudinal Research

label: Re3data
descr: Re3data is a global registry of research data repositories that covers research data repositories from different academic disciplines.

label: Sci2sci
descr: A platform designed to facilitate the search, publication, and acquisition of datasets.

label: Mexca
descr: Mexca is an open-source Python package which aims to capture human emotion expressions from videos in a single pipeline.

label: Data validation
keyQuestions: How can we ensure the quality and accuracy of the data? How can we store the data reproducibly?

label: FAIR data
descr: The FAIR Guiding Principles for scientific data management and stewardship.

label: RDMkit
descr: The Research Data Management toolkit for Life Sciences. Best practices and guidelines to help you make your data FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable).

label: Diffchecker
descr: Diffchecker will compare text to find the difference between two text files. Just paste your files and click Find Difference

label: Preprocessing guidelines for psychophysiological outcomes
descr: This is a collection of helpful papers and guidelines on how to preprocess different psychophysiological data.
path: Data validation > Preprocessing > Preprocessing guidelines for psychophysiological outcomes

label: EEG
descr: What is an EEG?
path: Data validation > Preprocessing > Type of data > EEG

label: AFNI
descr: AFNI (Analysis of Functional NeuroImages) is a leading software suite of C, Python, R programs and shell scripts primarily developed for the analysis and display of multiple MRI modalities: anatomical, functional MRI (FMRI) and diffusion weighted (DW) data.
path: Data validation > Preprocessing > Type of data > fMRI_val > AFNI

label: SPM
descr: Statistical Parametric Mapping refers to the construction and assessment of spatially extended statistical processes used to test hypotheses about functional imaging data.
path: Data validation > Preprocessing > Type of data > fMRI_val > SPM

label: FSL
descr: FSL is a comprehensive library of analysis tools for FMRI, MRI and DTI brain imaging data.
path: Data validation > Preprocessing > Type of data > fMRI_val > FSL

label: Freesurfer
descr: An open source neuroimaging toolkit for processing, analyzing, and visualizing human brain MR images
path: Data validation > Preprocessing > Type of data > fMRI_val > Freesurfer

label: DICOM tags
descr: Do you want to know where a specific information is saved in the DICOM file of your imaging data. Check out DICOM Tags.
path: Data validation > Preprocessing > Type of data > fMRI_val > DICOM tags

label: Data analysis
keyQuestions: What are specific analysis pipelines and programs that can be used for specific types of data (e.g., EEG, (f)MRI, behavior)? || What open-source software is a good alternative to proprietary products? || Which tools allow complete replicability of an analysis pipeline, independent of the specific operating system of a user or continuous software updates? || How are results visualized in a captivating, yet transparent and maximally inclusive way?

label: neurosynth compose
descr: Perform custom neuroimaging meta-analyses entirely in the browser, and quickly get results in the cloud using automated analysis pipelines.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > fMRI_viz > neurosynth compose

label: Neurosynth
descr: NeuroSynth is for large-scale, automated synthesis of functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data. You can search for word associations and papers with specific MNI coordinates.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > fMRI_viz > Neurosynth

label: MRIcroGL
descr: MRIcroGL is a software program used for visualizing and analyzing medical imaging data, particularly MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) scans. It is a 3D viewer that allows researchers, clinicians, and students to examine brain images and perform various analyses, such as rendering images, exploring brain structures, and applying overlays to display additional information.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > fMRI_viz > MRIcroGL

label: MRIcron
descr: MRIcron is a widely used software tool for viewing and analyzing medical imaging data, particularly MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) scans. It provides a user-friendly interface for visualizing 2D and 3D images, enabling researchers and clinicians to explore anatomical structures, apply overlays for functional data, and conduct basic analyses.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > fMRI_viz > MRIcron

label: Nipype
descr: Nipype (Neuroimaging in Python: Pipelines and Interfaces) is an open-source Python library designed for building and executing neuroimaging analysis pipelines.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > fMRI_viz > Nipype

label: fMRI analysis course
descr: Learn how to design and analyze fMRI experiments in this free course.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > fMRI_viz > fMRI analysis course

label: RepoNeuroVis
descr: A practical guide for generating reproducible and programmatic neuroimaging visualizations.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > fMRI_viz > RepoNeuroVis

label: Brain Atlas Framework
descr: For Neuroimaging beginners: Ever found yourself lost in the world of atlases and needed someone to create a summary to find an atlas best suited for your study? Here it is.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > fMRI_viz > Brain Atlas Framework

label: Web plot digitizer
descr: Helps you to reverse engineer data from visualizations by extracting the underlying numerical values.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Web plot digitizer

label: MolView
descr: You can use MolView to search through different scientific databases including compound databases, protein databases and spectral databases, and view records from these databases as interactive visualizations.

label: Scholar Goggler
descr: Generate your own word clouds using data from Google Scholar, PubMed, or Semantic Scholar.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Scholar Goggler

label: Pixabay
descr: Tons of license-free images.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Photos > Pixabay

label: Color converter
descr: If you need to find out the code for a certain color, check this handy converter.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Colors > Color converter

label: Cols4all
descr: An R package "for selecting color palettes. 'Color for all' refers to [the authors'] mission that colors should be usable for not just people with normal color vision, but also for people with color vision deficiency".
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Colors > Cols4all

label: Color oracle
descr: A piece of software that helps you tell whether your plot or slide is accessible to folk with different colour vision impairments.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Colors > Color oracle

label: Color picker
descr: Upload an image and pick the hex code of any color in the image.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Colors > Color picker

label: Adobe color wheel
descr: Generate fitting color palettes based on images.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Colors > Adobe color wheel

label: Color blindness simulator
descr: If you are looking for more information to learn about color blindness and all its details, would like to better understand the vision by simulating it or want to test themselves with some form of color blindness test.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Colors > Color blindness simulator

label: Laws of user experience
descr: Laws of UX is a collection of best practices that designers can consider when building user interfaces or visualizations.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Laws of user experience

label: RAWgraphs
descr: RAWGraphs is an open source data visualization framework built with the goal of making the visual representation of complex data easy for everyone.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Figure Creator > RAWgraphs

label: BioRender
descr: The all-in-one tool for research visualization in a free and paid verson. Visualize study designs and results, or even design whole posters using their tools and icons.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Figure Creator > BioRender

label: Canva
descr: Canva is amazing for creating content such as slides, figures and there are so many great (and free!) designs to choose from.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Figure Creator > Canva

label: Choose your plot
descr: No idea how to best plot your data? Have a look at this image.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Figure Creator > Choose your plot

label: Autodraw
descr: AutoDraw magically makes your doodles into nicer graphics by suggesting shapes based on what you drew.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Figure Creator > Autodraw

label: Brain code selector
descr: This tool summarized tools to visualize brain data in R, Python, and Matlab.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Figure Creator > Brain code selector

label: Make your own scatterplot
descr: This handy tool allows you to draw in scatterplot points and download a CSV file with the coordinates.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Figure Creator > Make your own scatterplot

label: Mermaid
descr: Mermaid lets you create diagrams and visualizations using text and code.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Figure Creator > Mermaid

label: BioIcons
descr: A free alternative to BioRender.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Icons > BioIcons

label: Flaticon
descr: Flaticon has a huge amount of free stickers and icons, ready to download and use.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Icons > Flaticon

label: Font Awesome
descr: Font Awesome has loads of free icons to choose from to use in presentations, posters, etc.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Icons > Font Awesome

label: Phylopic
descr: An open database of freely usable silhouettes of life forms.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Icons > Phylopic

label: Smart Servier Medical Art
descr: Servier Medical Art is your global source for over 3000 free, up-to-date medical images designed to meet your needs.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Icons > Smart Servier Medical Art

label: Health icons
descr: Free, open source health icons.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Icons > Health icons

label: Chemix
descr: Chemix is an online editor for drawing science lab diagrams and school experiments in Chemistry, Biology and Physics. The app provides easy sketching for both students and teachers.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Icons > Chemix

label: GitHub cheatsheet
descr: Confused by commit, stage, stash, fetch, etc. on GitHub? Here's the sheet for you.

label: fNIRS cheatsheet
descr: A hitchhiker's guide to fNIRS data analysis for beginners.

label: renv (R)
descr: Renvironments, a term coined by the package's name, refer to R project-specific environments that isolate the package versions and dependencies used in that project enabeling reproducible environments.

label: Docker
descr: Docker is a platform and tool designed to create, deploy, and manage applications using containerization. Containerization is a technology that allows you to package an application and its dependencies, including libraries, runtime, and system tools, into a single standardized unit called a 'container'. Containers provide an isolated and consistent environment for running applications, regardless of the underlying operating system or infrastructure.

label: Datapasta (R)
descr: This R package is 'about reducing resistance associated with copying and pasting data to and from R'. Copy data from Excel and paste it into R as a dataframe or tibble.

label: Neuroimaging resources
descr: List of ca. 300 resources supporting openness and reproducibility in neuroimaging.

label: PSPP
descr: GNU PSPP is a free and open-source software application used for statistical analysis of data. It is designed to provide similar functionality to proprietary software like IBM SPSS (Statistical Package for the Social Sciences). PSPP is part of the GNU Project, which aims to develop a complete, free, and open-source operating system.

label: SPSS
descr: IBM SPSS (Statistical Package for the Social Sciences) is a proprietary software application used for statistical analysis, data manipulation, and data visualization. It is widely utilized in social science research, business analytics, and academic settings for its comprehensive set of statistical tools and user-friendly interface.

label: FSBrain
descr: This R package "helps visualize surface-based brain structure data for large groups of subjects with very little code" and "also supports the computation of simple brain morphometry measures".
path: Data analysis > Analysis Framework > R > FSBrain

label: GGhelp
descr: An R package that "converts a natural language query into a 'ggplot2' command string".
path: Data analysis > Analysis Framework > R > GGhelp

label: GGplot tricks
descr: Some tricks from the R people to level up your ggplot game.
path: Data analysis > Analysis Framework > R > GGplot tricks

label: R visualization
descr: This is a great syllabus about visualizing data in R, held by Claus Wilke.
path: Data analysis > Analysis Framework > R > R visualization

label: R graph gallery
descr: A collection of charts made with the R programming language.
path: Data analysis > Analysis Framework > R > R graph gallery

label: Cheatsheets 1
descr: There are loads of cheat sheets to help you find your way around in R.
path: Data analysis > Analysis Framework > R > RStudio > Cheatsheets 1

label: Cheatsheets 2
descr: Another load of cheat sheets to help you find your way around in R.
path: Data analysis > Analysis Framework > R > RStudio > Cheatsheets 2

label: Jupyter Notebook
descr: Jupyter Notebook is an open-source web application that allows users to create and share documents containing live code, equations, visualizations, and narrative text. It's commonly used for interactive data analysis, data visualization, machine learning experimentation, and collaborative research across various programming languages.
path: Study design > Design framework > Python > Jupyter Notebook

label: Jupyter Notebook
descr: Jupyter Notebook is an open-source web application that allows users to create and share documents containing live code, equations, visualizations, and narrative text. It's commonly used for interactive data analysis, data visualization, machine learning experimentation, and collaborative research across various programming languages.
path: Study design > Design framework > Python > Jupyter Notebook

label: Cheatsheets
descr: A cheatsheet in Python is a concise reference guide that provides a quick overview of essential syntax, functions, methods, and concepts, aiding developers in writing code more efficiently.

label: Google Colab
descr: Google Colab (short for Colaboratory) is a free cloud-based platform that provides an interactive environment for writing and executing Python code, particularly well-suited for machine learning, data analysis, and research, with the added advantage of GPU acceleration.
path: Study design > Design framework > Python > Google Colab

label: Matlab
descr: MATLAB is a programming and numeric computing platform.

label: juicr
descr: juicr is a GUI interface to automated, semi-automated, and manual tools for extracting data from scientific images -- like scatter or bar plots that contain data, or other images with information that can be converted numerically or coordinates classified.

label: shinyDigitise
descr: shinyDigitise is an R package that builds upon the popular metaDigitise package and provides users with an interactive UI to help extraction of data from five different plot types.

label: Syllabus
descr: Resources for learning (and teaching) on how to conduct Meta-Analyses and Systematic Reviews

label: Metafor (R)
descr: Use the metafor package in R for your meta-analyses.

label: Coda
descr: Use Coda, a machine-readable history of cooperation research, to search, select and visualize studies for on-demand meta-analysis.

label: Metalab
descr: This website features interactive, community-augmented meta-analysis tools for cognitive development research.

label: Templates
descr: A primer and tutorial paper on "Conducting a meta-analysis in the age of open science: Tools, tips, and practical recommendations", including nine templates free for use, from preregistration to code to data.

label: Neuroquery
descr: NeuroQuery is a tool for meta-analysis of neuroimaging studies, relating text queries to activations as well as associations between terms used together in neuroimaging publications. More info in the corresponding paper.

label: Writing
keyQuestions: What is the scope of the paper? || What is the target audience and journal? || How to write a convincing abstract? || How to properly credit authors? || How to find and cite sources correctly? || How to structure a manuscript? || Which frameworks allow to conveniently write a reproducible manuscript?

label: Tenzing
descr: Use the Tenzing ShinyApp for quickly and easily documenting contributorship.

label: CRediT
descr: Use the CRedit Author Statement by Brandt et al. (2015, Learned Publishing) to report each authors proper contribution to a manuscript.

label: Scite
descr: A platform for evaluating scientific articles via smart citations, which allows users to assess how a publication has ben cited.

label: Grateful
descr: Use the grateful package in R to automatically create a reference list for all your used R packages.

label: Writing effectively
descr: If you want to know how to write effectively, watch this video.

label: Acronymify
descr: If you need a cool and catchy acronym for your paper, project, etc. check out Acronymify.

label: List of acronyms
descr: Don't waste time collating a list or table of abbreviations manually. This tool does it for you.

label: Quillbot
descr: Paraphrase like the awesome boss you are using QuillBot.

label: Statcheck
descr: To check a PDF, DOCX or HTML file for errors in statistical reporting, upload it to Statcheck. Some journals even officially request this now (e.g., Psychological Science).

label: Grammarly
descr: Work with an AI writing partner that helps you find the words you need to write that tricky email, to get your point across, to keep your work moving.

label: PaperPal
descr: Boost your chances of success with real-time, subject-specific language suggestions that help you write better, faster!

label: Preprint templates
descr: Amazing and useful Word templates for typesetting preprints. Because your preprint should be a #prettypreprint and we don't have time for endless formatting.
path: Writing > Writing Framework > Word > Preprint templates

label: APA-style Word template
descr: A Word template in APA7 style for student papers. Word and Google Docs versions exist
path: Writing > Writing Framework > Word > APA-style Word template

label: Papaja
descr: If you want to create reproducible manuscripts including tables directly from your data in R, use the papaja package.

label: Overleaf
descr: Overleaf is an online collaborative platform used for creating, editing, and sharing scientific documents, particularly LaTeX-based documents, making it popular among researchers and academics for collaborative writing and publishing.

label: Zotero
descr: Zotero is a free and open-source reference management software that helps users collect, organize, cite, and share research sources and bibliographic information. You can also connect it with Rmarkdown for reproducible workflows.

label: Mendeley
descr: Mendeley is a reference management tool and academic social network that assists researchers in organizing, sharing, and citing research papers and other scholarly materials.

label: Citavi
descr: Citavi is a reference management and knowledge organization software designed to help researchers, students, and academics manage sources, citations, and research tasks efficiently. Check if your institution got a licence for the software.

label: Endnote
descr: EndNote is a commercial reference management software that enables researchers, writers, and academics to organize, store, and cite references and bibliographic information in their documents. Check if your institution got a licence for the software.

label: Reference management comparison
descr: Reference management comparison is a table which evaluates and contrasts various reference management software tools. Additionally, it determines their features, functionalities, and suitability for specific research and academic needs.
path: Writing > Citations > Citation Managers > Reference management comparison

label: BibTeX
descr: Bibliography & reference generator that works quite well with Rmd/Papaja.

label: Citation Diversity Statement
descr: To increase awareness about citation bias and mitigate it, by checking for and transparently reporting proportions of citing male and female first and last authors, use the citation diversity statement by Zurn et al. (2020, TICS).

label: Recite
descr: To check your in-text citations and reference lists for errors, use Reciteworks.

label: Citation Gecko
descr: Gecko is here to help you find the most relevant papers to your research and give you a more complete sense of the research landscape.

label: Publication
keyQuestions: Where to upload data, code, materials, and/or a preprint?  || Is the published data FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable)?  || How to write a cover letter? || How to write a rebuttal to reviewer comments?

label: JANE
descr: If you dont know who to suggest as a reviewer or what journal to submit your paper to, check out JANE.

label: Journal Rater
descr: If you want to know about the review process and manuscript handling, check out the Journal Rater by PhD Voice. Because lifes too short to put up with Reviewer 2s.

label: Journal suggester
descr: Just paste your abstract and get some suggestions for journals you can submit to.

label: Journal abbreviations
descr: This list shows the abbreviations used for journal titles as cited works.

label: SciRev
descr: If you want to know how long the review process for a specific journal is, or people's experience with publishing there, check SciRev.

label: Open Science Framework
descr: The Open Science Framework (OSF) is a web-based platform that facilitates collaboration and supports the entire research lifecycle by providing tools for project organization, data sharing, collaboration, and transparency. Consider the hosting server location and its data policity before sharing the data.
path: Publication > Resource Sharing > Data_resource > Open Science Framework

label: DataCite
descr: Ensure that research outputs and DataCite ensures that resources are openly available and connected.

label: FigShare
descr: The all in one repository - a home for papers, FAIR data and non-traditional research outputs that is easy to use and ready now.

label: Zenodo
descr: Zenodo is an open-access repository that allows researchers to store, share, and publish their research outputs, including datasets, code, preprints, and other scholarly materials, ensuring long-term preservation and accessibility. Consider the hosting server location and its data policity before sharing the data.

label: NeuroVault
descr: NeuroVault is an online platform that enables researchers in the field of neuroscience to share, analyze, and collaboratively work with neuroimaging data and statistical maps.

label: Open Science Framework
descr: The Open Science Framework (OSF) is a web-based platform that facilitates collaboration and supports the entire research lifecycle by providing tools for project organization, data sharing, collaboration, and transparency. Consider the hosting server location and its data policity before sharing the data.
path: Publication > Resource Sharing > Data_resource > Open Science Framework

label: Zenodo
descr: Zenodo is an open-access repository that allows researchers to store, share, and publish their research outputs, including datasets, code, preprints, and other scholarly materials, ensuring long-term preservation and accessibility. Consider the hosting server location and its data policity before sharing the data.

label: GitHub
descr: GitHub is a web-based platform for version control and collaborative software development, allowing developers to host, review, and manage code repositories.

label: Open Science Framework
descr: The Open Science Framework (OSF) is a web-based platform that facilitates collaboration and supports the entire research lifecycle by providing tools for project organization, data sharing, collaboration, and transparency. Consider the hosting server location and its data policity before sharing the data.
path: Publication > Resource Sharing > Data_resource > Open Science Framework

label: Protocols
descr: A secure platform for developing and sharing reproducible methods.

label: Zenodo
descr: Zenodo is an open-access repository that allows researchers to store, share, and publish their research outputs, including datasets, code, preprints, and other scholarly materials, ensuring long-term preservation and accessibility. Consider the hosting server location and its data policity before sharing the data.

label: GitHub
descr: GitHub is a web-based platform for version control and collaborative software development, allowing developers to host, review, and manage code repositories.

label: Sherpa Romeo
descr: If you are not sure whether you are allowed to upload a preprint prior to journal submission.

label: MetArXiv
descr: A preprint platform for publications related to meta research.

label: PsyArXiv
descr: A preprint platform for publications related to Psychology.

label: BioArXiv
descr: A preprint platform for publications related to Biology and Neuroscience.

label: PeerCommunityIn
descr: PCI is a non-profit organization of researchers offering peer review, recommendation and publication of scientific articles in open access for free.

label: PreReview
descr: Provide and receive constructive feedback on preprints from an international community of your peers.

label: PsychArchives
descr: A disciplinary repository for psychological science and neighboring disciplines. Accommodating 20 different digital research object (DRO) types, including articles, preprints, research data, code, supplements, preregistrations, tests and multimedia objects, PsychArchives provides a digital space that integrates all research-related content relevant to psychology.

label: TOP Guidelines
descr: The TOP Guidelines include eight modular standards, each with three levels of increasing stringency of research published in academic journals.

label: Octopus
descr: Octopus is a free pulishing platform for scholarly research, including peer review and quality assessment.

label: ORCID
descr: Get an ORCID - an "Open Researcher and Contributor ID" which is a persistent digital identifier that you own and control, and that distinguishes you from every other researcher. Link your projects and output to your ORCID.

label: Dissemination
keyQuestions: How to design a poster for a conference? || How to prepare a scientific presentation? || How to present your research to a lay audience?

label: Pint of Science
descr: Pint of Science is non-profit and organised by a grass-root community of thousands of scientists across the world, organizing events for the public to hear about and question the latest discoveries being made.

label: Psychology conference timelines
descr: A spreadsheet of many psychological conferences and their timelines.

label: Designing conference posters
descr: Tips on how to design the perfect poster for a conference.

label: Canva
descr: Canva is a web-based graphic design platform that provides users with a wide range of tools and templates to create visually appealing designs for various purposes, from social media graphics to presentations.
path: Data analysis > Data Visualization > Figure Creator > Canva

label: Illustrator
descr: Illustrator refers to Adobe Illustrator, a vector graphics editor used to create and manipulate digital artwork, illustrations, logos, and other visual content with precision and scalability. Check if your institution got a licence for the software.

label: PowerPoint
descr: Microsoft PowerPoint is a popular presentation software used to create slideshows and presentations that incorporate text, images, animations, and multimedia elements to convey information and ideas effectively. Check if your institution got a licence for the software.

label: Better posters
descr: A video on how to create a better research poster in less time (#betterposter Generation 1)

label: Font size calculator
descr: A German tool to calculate accessible font sizes.

label: PowerPoint
descr: Microsoft PowerPoint is a popular presentation software used to create slideshows and presentations that incorporate text, images, animations, and multimedia elements to convey information and ideas effectively. Check if your institution got a licence for the software.

label: Slidesgo
descr: Slidesgo is a platform that offers a collection of professionally designed, customizable presentation templates for various topics and purposes, making it easier for users to create visually appealing slideshows.

label: Talk invitations
descr: Have you been invited to speak somewhere? Here are some questions you might (and should) ask beforehand.

label: Prezi
descr: Prezi is a multimedia platform where users can create slide presentations, videos, or designs to share. Whether starting from a blank canvas or using one of the templates from the site's vast library, users have many options.

label: In Mind Magazine
descr: In-Mind Magazine, operated by the In-Mind Foundation, is an online quarterly publication that aims to make psychology accessible by offering peer-reviewed articles and content that bridges the gap between scientific research and the general public's understanding.In-Mind Magazine, operated by the In-Mind Foundation, is an online quarterly publication that aims to make psychology accessible by offering peer-reviewed articles and content that bridges the gap between scientific research and the general public's understanding.

label: Gehirn und Geist
descr: "Gehirn und Geist" is a German-language popular science magazine focused on psychology and neuroscience, providing articles and insights for readers interested in understanding the human mind and brain.

label: Scientific American
descr: Scientific American is a well-known popular science magazine that publishes articles covering a wide range of scientific disciplines, offering insights and discoveries to a broad audience.

label: APS Observer
descr: APS Observer is the monthly magazine of the Association for Psychological Science (APS), providing news, insights, and research highlights related to the field of psychology and the activities of APS.

label: APA Monitor on Psychology
descr: APA Monitor on Psychology is the monthly magazine published by the American Psychological Association (APA), offering news, features, and articles on psychology-related topics for psychologists and the general public.
path: Dissemination > Writing_diss > APA Monitor on Psychology

label: Twitter
descr: Twitter is a social media platform that enables users to share and read short posts called "tweets," allowing for real-time updates, discussions, and information sharing in a concise format. At the moment rebranded to "X".

label: Mastodon
descr: Mastodon is an open-source, decentralized social media platform that operates as a network of independently run instances, allowing users to communicate and share content while retaining control over their data and community.

label: TikTok
descr: TikTok is a social media platform that allows users to create and share short videos set to music or other audio, known for its popularity among younger generations.

label: Instagram
descr: Instagram is a photo and video sharing social media platform that enables users to upload, edit, and share visual content with their followers.

label: YouTube
descr: YouTube is a video-sharing platform where users can upload, watch, and interact with a wide variety of videos, spanning from entertainment to education.

label: MRI_deface
descr: Defacing of MR Images to protect rights of participants
path: Data validation > Preprocessing > Type of data > fMRI_val > MRIDeface

label: Error Tight by Julia Strand
descr: Error Tight is a set of exercises for lab groups to identify places in their research workflow where errors may occur and pinpoint ways to address them. It is intended to be completed during a lab meeting.

label: Zettlr
descr: Zettlr is a free and open-source note-taking application that works with Markdown files. Files may be exported and imported from a variety of different formats using an integration with Pandoc, whilst integration with reference managers allows for insertion of citations into documents.

label: TransMIT Center fuer wissenschaftlich-psychologische Dienstleistungen (DGPs)
descr: Various documents are required for the application. These should be created in a uniform format. For this reason, the Ethics Committee provides templates for the application form and the test subject materials. This makes it much easier for applicants to prepare their applications. As the use of the templates also facilitates the work of the Ethics Committee, these templates should generally be used.
path: Ethical considerations and approvals > TransMIT Center fuer wissenschaftlich-psychologische Dienstleistungen (DGPs)

label: GENEMEDE Metadata Standard
descr: GENEMEDE (GEneric NEuro MEtadata DEscriptors) is a generic metadata framework that may be used to comprehensively describe a neuroscience experiment
path: Data structure and management > GENEMEDE Metadata Standard

label: VALID Checklist
descr: A tool that helps you assess and improve the validity of your project by providing you with a tailor-made checklist specific to your project

label: Electronic lab notebooks
descr: Electronic laboratory notebooks (ELNs) play a central role in the documentation, planning, execution and evaluation of scientific experiments. In psychology, these exist primarily in the form of measurement protocols, but are also available in electronic form
path: Documentation and flexibility > Electronic lab notebooks

label: DataWiz
descr: DataWiz is a free data management system that helps prepare research data. DataWiz facilitates high-quality documentation in accordance with current standards, enables collaborative and distributed work on projects, ensures the long-term reusability of research data

label: OpenMinds
descr: The open Metadata Initiative for Neuroscience Data Structures, short openMINDS, is a metadata framework that develops and maintains a set of metadata models as well as libraries of controlled terminologies, brain atlases, and common coordinate spaces for neuroscience graph databases

label: PowerLMM.js
descr: A tool for power analysis of longitudinal linear mixed-effects models (LMMs) - with support for missing data, plus non-inferiority and equivalence tests

label: Open Pain
descr: An open access data sharing platform for brain imaging studies of human pain

label: TUNA App
descr: It is a open source picture database with 796 pictures and a desktop app to select the stimuli. The stimuli have been validated in a representative us sample and a large european student sample

label: LimeSurvey
descr: A simple, quick and anonymous online survey tool

label: SoSciSurvey
descr: An online survey tool that is free for non-commercial use

label: Mask_explorer
descr: Mask_explorer is developed for the spatial validation of data sets intended for group fMRI analysis. It helps detect subjects with potentially problematic data and consequently enables inspection of the data. It is able to estimate subject-specific masks of valid data; compute, explore, and export SM images and binary group masks; automatically detect outlying masks

label: jamovi
descr: jamovi is a free, open statistical GUI-based software, based on R. It allows to export the commands from the GUI as an R-script and is a great alternative to SPSS and a nice way to get into R using a GUI

label: JASP
descr: JASP offers standard analysis procedures in both their classical and Bayesian form.
